questions.Q: A ball of mass 0.20 kg moving at $$3.6\,\text{m/s}$$ on a horizontal floor collides with a vertical wall. The ball rebounds with a speed of $$3.2\,\text{m/s}$$ . The ball was in contact with the wall for $$12\,\text{ms}$$. Assuming that the force depends on time according to the figure, the maximum force exerted on the ball is:
questions.E: Let the initial velocity be positive. The rebound velocity is then negative. $$\\$$ Initial momentum: $$p_i= 0.20\,\text{kg} \times 3.6\,\text{m/s} = 0.72 \, \text{N s}\\ $$ Final momentum: $$p_f=0.20\,\text{kg} \times (−3.2)\,\text{kg} = −0.64\, \text{N s }\\$$ The change in momentum of the ball is: $$\\ \Delta p=p_f-p_i=−0.64 − 0.72 = −1.36\,\text{N s}\text{.} \\ $$ The magnitude of $$\Delta p$$ is equal to the area under the force–time graph. $$\\$$The area is $$A= \frac{1}{2} \times 12 \times 10^{-3}\,\text{s} \times F_{max}$$ and so:$$\\ A= \frac{1}{2} \times 12 \times 10^{-3}\,\text{s} \times F_{max}=|\Delta p|= 1.36\, \text{N s} \\ \therefore F_{max} = 0.227 \times 10^3\, \text{N} \approx 2.3 \times 10^2\, \text{N}$$

questions.Q: A ball of mass 0.0750 kg is travelling horizontally with a speed of  $$2.20\,\text{m/s}$$. It strikes a vertical wall and rebounds horizontally. Due to the collision with the wall, $$20\,\%$$ of the ball's initial kinetic energy is dissipated. The ball strikes the wall at time $$t = 0$$ and leaves the wall at time $$t = T$$.  The sketch graph shows how the force $$F$$ that the wall exerts on the ball is assumed to vary with time $$t$$. The time $$T$$ is measured electronically to equal $$0.0894\,\text{s}$$. The maximum force exerted on the ball is:
questions.E: The ball's velocity after rebounding is found from $$ \frac{1}{2}m(v^\prime)^2 =0.8\times \frac{1}{2}mv^2 \therefore v^{\prime}=\sqrt{0.8}v=\sqrt{0.8}(2.20\,\text{m/s})=1.97 \,\text{m/s} \text{.} \\ $$ Let the initial velocity be positive. The rebound velocity is then negative. $$\\$$ Initial momentum: $$p_i= mv=0.0750\,\text{kg} \times 2.20\,\text{m/s} = 0.17 \, \text{N s}\\ $$ Final momentum: $$p_f=mv^{\prime}=0.0750\,\text{kg} \times (−1.97)\,\text{kg} = −0.15\, \text{N s }\\$$ The change in momentum of the ball is: $$\\ \Delta p=p_f-p_i=−0.15 − 0.17 = −0.32\,\text{N s}\text{.} \\ $$ The magnitude of $$\Delta p$$ is equal to the area under the force–time graph. $$\\$$The area is $$A= \frac{1}{2} \times 0.0894\,\text{s} \times F_{max}$$ and so:$$\\ A= \frac{1}{2} \times 0.0894\,\text{s} \times F_{max}=|\Delta p|= 0.32\, \text{N s} \\ \therefore F_{max} = 7.16\, \text{N}$$

questions.Q: A baseball is hit with a bat and, as a result, its direction is completely reversed and its speed is doubled. If the contact time of the ball with the bat lasts 0.31 s and  the initial ball's speed is $$20\,\text{m/s}$$, the average acceleration of the ball is:
questions.E: Let the initial velocity be positive. The rebound velocity is then negative. $$\\$$ Initial momentum: $$p_i= mv\\ $$ Final momentum: $$p_f=m(-2v)=-2mv\\$$ The change in momentum of the ball is: $$\\ \Delta p=p_f-p_i=-2mv − mv = -3mv\text{.} \\ $$ The magnitude of $$\Delta p$$ is equal to $$F_{avg}\Delta t\\$$ By Newton's second law  $$F_{avg}=ma\\$$ So, $$a=\frac{3v}{\Delta t}=\frac{3(20\,\text{m/s})}{0.31\,\text{s}}=193.5\,\text{m/s}^2 \\$$ This is a very large acceleration!. About 20 times the acceleration due to gravity.

questions.Q: A jet of water leaves a hose and hits a wall where its velocity is brought to rest. If the hose cross-sectional area is $$25\,\text{cm}^2$$, the velocity of the water is $$50\,\text{m/s}$$ and the density of the water is $$1000\,\frac{\text{ kg}}{\text{m}^3}$$, the force acting on the wall is:
questions.E: In one second, a jet of water $$50\,\text{m}$$ long hits the wall. So $$\\$$ volume of water hitting the wall every second = $$0.0025 \times 50 = 0.125\,\text{m}^3\\$$ mass of water hitting the wall every second = $$0.125\times 1000 = 125 \,\text{kg}\\$$ momentum of water hitting the wall every second = $$125 \times 50 = 6250\,\text{ kg m s}^{ –1}=6250\,\text{ Ns}\\$$ This water is all brought to rest,$$\\ \therefore$$ change in momentum, $$\Delta p = 6250\,\text{Ns}\\ \therefore F=\frac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}=\frac{6250\,\text{Ns}}{1\,\text{s}}=6250\,\text{N}$$

questions.Q: In a billiard game the player strikes the cue ball of mass $$m=0.16\,\text{kg}$$. The force applied to it changes in time as shown in the figure. If the velocity of the cue ball is $$2.0\,\text{m/s}$$ the time of interaction between the cue ball and the cue is:
questions.E: The change of momentum of the cue ball is given by $$\Delta p = mv_f-mv_i=mv_f$$, where $$v_i$$ and $$v_f$$ are the initial and final velocities of the cue ball. $$\\$$This change of momentum is the area under the curve of force acting over time. $$\\$$From the graph, $$\\ \Delta p =\text{Area}\approx\,\text{Area of rectangle of base}\, \Delta t \,\text{and height}\,  F\text{,}\, \text{i.e.,} \Delta t F$$, where $$F=1\,\text{N}\\$$  So, $$\Delta t = \frac{mv}{F}=\frac{(0.16\,\text{kg})(2.0\,\text{m/s})}{1.0\,\text{N}}=0.3\,\text{s}$$

questions.Q: A constant force $$\vec{F}=F_0\hat{i}$$ acts on a particle of mass $$m$$ during the time $$t=0$$ to $$t=t_0$$. The magnitude of the force against time is shown in the figure. The particle is at rest at $$t=0$$, the velocity of the particle at $$t=t_0$$ is:
questions.E: The change of momentum of the particle is given by $$\Delta p = mv_f-mv_i=mv_f$$, where $$v_i$$ and $$v_f$$ are the initial and final velocities of particle. $$\\$$This change of momentum is the area under the curve of force acting over time. $$\\$$From the graph, $$\\ \Delta p =\text{Area}=\,\text{Area of rectangle of base}\, t_0 \,\text{and height}\,  F_0\text{,}\, \text{i.e.,}\, t_0 F_0\\$$  So, $$mv_f = F_0t_0 \therefore v_f= \frac{F_0}{m}t_0\\$$ Alternative solution: $$\\$$ Given that the force acting on the particle is constant, it moves with constant acceleration $$a$$, i.e., $$a=\frac{F_0}{m}\text{.}\\$$ Thus, the particle's velocity is given by $$v=at=\frac{F_0}{m}t\text{.}\\$$ At time $$t=t_0$$, the velocity becomes $$v_f=\frac{F_0}{m}t_0$$

questions.Q: The graph shows the variation with time of the force acting on a body that is moving in a straight line. The resulting change in momentum of the body is:
questions.E: The change of momentum of the body is given by $$\Delta p = mv_f-mv_i=mv_f$$, where $$v_i$$ and $$v_f$$ are the initial and final velocities of the body. $$\\$$This change of momentum is the area under the curve of force acting over time. $$\\$$From the graph, $$\\ \Delta p =\text{Area of square + area of trapezoid}=(2\,\text{s})(2\,\text{N})+\frac{1}{2}(2\,\text{s})(2\,\text{N}+4\,\text{N})=10\,\text{Ns}  $$

questions.Q: The graph shows the variation with time of the force acting on a body that is moving in a straight line. The resulting change in momentum of the body is:
questions.E: The change of momentum of the body is given by $$\Delta p = mv_f-mv_i=mv_f$$, where $$v_i$$ and $$v_f$$ are the initial and final velocities of the body. $$\\$$This change of momentum is the area under the curve of force acting over time. $$\\$$From the graph, $$\\ \Delta p =\text{Area of triangle + area of rectangle}=\frac{1}{2}(2\,\text{s})(3\,\text{N})+(2\,\text{s})(3\,\text{N})=9\,\text{Ns}  $$

questions.Q: The graph shows the variation with time of the force acting on a body of mass $$m$$ that is moving in a straight line and starts at rest at $$t=0$$. The velocity of the body as a function of time for $$0<t<t_0$$ is:
questions.E: The change of momentum of the body is given by $$\Delta p = mv_f-mv_i=mv_f$$, where $$v_i=0$$ and $$v_f=v$$ are the velocities at $$t=0$$ and $$t=t$$. $$\\$$This change of momentum is the area under the curve of force acting over time. $$\\$$From the graph, $$\\ \Delta p=mv =\text{Area of triangle}=\frac{1}{2}(t)(F)$$ where $$F$$ is the force at time $$t$$ which it is obtained as $$\frac{F_0}{t_0}=\frac{F}{t}\\$$ From this relationship, $$F=\frac{F_0}{t_0}t\\$$ Thus, $$mv=\frac{1}{2}\frac{F_0}{t_0}t^2 \therefore v=\frac{1}{2}\frac{F_0}{mt_0}t^2\text{,}$$ for $$0<t<t_0$$

questions.Q: The graph shows the variation with time of the force acting on a body moving in a straight line and starts at rest at $$t=0$$. Out of the following statements the one correct is:

A.opt: The body's speed at $$t=3t_0$$ is twice as much as at $$t=2t_0$$
The body's speeds are equal at $$t=\frac{3}{2}t_0$$ and $$t=\frac{5}{2}t_0$$
The body's speed is maximum at $$t=2t_0$$
The body's speed is zero at $$t=3t_0$$

questions.E: The change of momentum of the body is $$\Delta p \propto \Delta v=v_f-v_i$$, where $$v_i=0$$ and $$v_f=v$$ are the velocities at $$t=0$$ and $$t=t$$. $$\\$$The change of momentum is the area under the curve of force acting over time.$$\\$$ So, $$\\ \Delta v_1=v_1-0=v_1$$ for the time interval $$t=t_0$$ to $$t=2t_0$$ is $$A_1\\$$ $$\Delta v_2=v_2-0=v_2$$ for the time interval $$t=t_0$$ to $$t=3t_0$$ is $$A_1+A_2=2A_1\\$$ Thus, $$v_2=2v_1$$

questions.Q: A molecule of mass $$5\times 10^{-23}\,\text{kg}$$ moving at a speed of $$500\,\text{ m/s}$$ hits a surface at $$\theta=60^{\circ}$$ to the normal and rebounds without loss of speed at $$\theta=60^{\circ}$$ to the normal as shown in figure. If the impact lasts $$0.22\,\text{ns}$$, the value of the mean force on the molecule is:
questions.E: Notice that $$|u|=|v| =420\,\text{m/s}$$  and $$\theta=60^{\circ}\\$$ Initial $$x$$ component of momentum: $$p_{ix}= mu_x=mv\cos \theta \\$$ Initial $$y$$ component of momentum: $$p_{iy}=mu_y= -mv\sin\theta \\$$ Final $$x$$ component of momentum: $$p_{fx}=mv_x= -mv\cos \theta \\$$ Final $$y$$ component of momentum: $$p_{fy}=mv_y= -mv\sin\theta \\$$ So, $$\\ \Delta p_x=p_{fx}-p_{ix}=-2mv\cos\theta=-2(5\times 10^{-26}\,\text{kg})(500\,\text{m/s})\cos(60^{\circ})=-2.5\times 10^{-23}\,\text{Ns}\\$$ $$\Delta p_y=p_{fy}-p_{iy}=0\\$$ Thus, $$\\ F=\frac{\Delta p_x}{\Delta t}=|-\frac{2.5\times 10^{-23}\,\text{Ns}}{0.22 \times 10^{-9}\,\text{s}}|=1.14\times 10^{-13}\,\text{N}$$
